title: AMC 8
description: The AMC 8 is the premier middle school mathematics competition in the United States, serving as the foundational entry point for the elite Olympiad pipeline. It is prestigious for its ability to identify mathematical talent early through non-routine problems that emphasize creative application over rote memorization. Success here is a key indicator for future performance in high-stakes high school contests like the AMC 10 and 12.
format: 25 multiple-choice questions in 40 minutes; No calculators allowed.
eligibility: Grade 8 or below; Under 14.5 years of age on competition day.
howToApply: 1. Contact school math coordinator. 2. Register via the MAA AMC portal. 3. Pay the registration fee by the Late Deadline.

title: AIME I
description: The American Invitational Mathematics Examination (AIME) is the high-stakes filter used to select the nation's top mathematical thinkers for the USAMO. It is prestigious due to its difficulty, where every answer is an integer between 0 and 999, making guessing statistically impossible. For many elite students, achieving a high AIME score is a primary goal in their academic career.
format: 15 short-answer questions in 3 hours; No partial credit.
eligibility: Qualification via top 2.5% of AMC 10 or top 5% of AMC 12.
howToApply: 1. Qualify through AMC 10/12. 2. Receive invitation from MAA. 3. Take exam at registered test center.

title: HMMT February
description: The Harvard-MIT Mathematics Tournament is widely considered one of the most intellectually demanding and prestigious math tournaments globally for high schoolers. Organized by students at Harvard and MIT, it draws 1,000 top competitors to tackle problems that exceed the difficulty of national standardized exams. Winning here is a definitive signal of elite mathematical proficiency to top-tier university admissions.
format: Individual Subject Tests (50 min) -> Team Round (60 min) -> Guts Round (80 min live speed round).
eligibility: High school students; Teams of 6-8.
howToApply: 1. Enter the lottery in the preceding autumn. 2. Confirm waitlist status in January. 3. Submit final rosters and waivers.

title: Stanford Math Tournament (SMT)
description: The Stanford Math Tournament is a prestigious student-run event that brings together the best young mathematicians from across the United States. It is interesting for its 'Power Round,' which challenges teams to solve proof-based problems centered on a single advanced mathematical topic. The event provides a unique window into the collegiate mathematical culture at Stanford.
format: Individual Subject Tests -> Power Round (80-min proof) -> Guts Round -> Team Round.
eligibility: High school students; Teams of up to 8.
howToApply: 1. Register online during the January window. 2. Choose between In-person or Online tracks. 3. Pay team registration fee.

title: Caltech Math Meet (CMM)
description: The Caltech Math Meet is a high-intensity event designed to test the limits of mathematical problem-solving speed and depth. It is prestigious for its inclusion of an 'Integration Bee' and a team-based 'Power Round' that is often completed virtually before the campus finale. Participating in this meet offers students a chance to engage with the world-class STEM community in Pasadena.
format: Power Round (Asynchronous) -> Individual Round -> Integration Bee -> Team Round.
eligibility: High school students; Teams of 6.
howToApply: 1. Register team via official portal. 2. Complete asynchronous Power Round. 3. Attend in-person finale at Caltech.

title: Regeneron Science Talent Search (STS)
description: Often referred to as the 'Junior Nobel Prize,' the Regeneron STS is the nation's oldest and most prestigious science research competition for high school seniors. It recognizes students who demonstrate exceptional promise in scientific research through original, independent experimentation and data analysis. Finalists travel to Washington D.C. to present their work to world-renowned scientists and compete for million-dollar awards.
format: Application Review -> Top 300 Scholar Selection -> Top 40 Finalist Selection -> Finals Week in D.C.
eligibility: High school seniors in the US or US citizens abroad.
howToApply: 1. Complete independent research project. 2. Submit application with research report. 3. Provide recommendations and transcripts.

title: Regeneron ISEF (Finals)
description: The Regeneron International Science and Engineering Fair is the largest and most prestigious pre-collegiate science fair in the world. It provides a global stage for more than 1,700 students to showcase their independent research and compete for nearly $9 million in prizes. Winning at ISEF is a transformative achievement that often leads to significant university scholarships and international recognition.
format: Qualify at Regional/State Fair -> Global Finals (Poster Defense and Judging).
eligibility: Grades 9-12; Qualification via affiliated regional or state fair.
howToApply: 1. Win top prize at local affiliated fair. 2. Receive advancement invitation. 3. Prepare final presentation for Phoenix 2026.

title: F=ma Exam
description: The F=ma exam is the critical first step in selecting the U.S. Physics Team to compete at the International Physics Olympiad. It is prestigious for its singular focus on classical mechanics, requiring students to solve complex problems using only algebra and trigonometry. As an online-only competition in 2026, it tests the purest form of physics intuition under strict time constraints.
format: 75-minute exam; 25 multiple-choice questions focusing on classical mechanics.
eligibility: High school students; US Citizens or Legal Residents.
howToApply: 1. School registers via AAPT. 2. Verify technical proctoring infrastructure. 3. Administer exam during designated window.

title: USA Biolympiad (USABO) Open Exam
description: The USABO is the premier biology competition for high schoolers in the United States, aiming to identify the four students who represent the nation internationally. It is prestigious for testing knowledge across the entire spectrum of biological sciences at a level far exceeding standard AP curricula. The Open Exam is the massive first round that filters for the top 10% of biological minds in the country.
format: 50-minute online multiple-choice exam.
eligibility: High school students; US Citizens or Legal Residents.
howToApply: 1. Register with a local test center or school. 2. Complete CEE registration. 3. Take proctored exam on February 4.

title: Math Kangaroo
description: With over 6 million participants worldwide, Math Kangaroo is the most extensive and accessible international math competition in existence. It is interesting for its focus on logical reasoning and approachable, visual problems that foster a love for mathematics in younger students. The competition's global reach allows students to see their performance compared to peers from dozens of countries.
format: One round: 75-minute multiple-choice test (24-30 questions).
eligibility: Grades 1-12.
howToApply: 1. Register online by February 1. 2. Choose a local test center or online option. 3. Attend competition on March 19.

title: Purple Comet! Math Meet
description: The Purple Comet! Math Meet is a unique, free international team competition that emphasizes collaborative problem solving. It is interesting because teams can choose their own 60-to-90-minute window during a ten-day period, making it highly flexible for schools worldwide. It encourages a community-driven approach to high-level mathematics without the barriers of registration fees.
format: Team round: 20-30 questions; 60 mins (MS) or 90 mins (HS).
eligibility: Middle and High School students; Teams of up to 6.
howToApply: 1. Teachers register teams for free. 2. Log in during the 10-day window. 3. Submit team answers online.

title: American Regions Mathematics League (ARML)
description: ARML is known as the 'World Series of Mathematics' and is unique because students compete on large regional teams of 15 students rather than for their individual schools. It is highly prestigious and social, featuring a high-octane atmosphere at four national sites. Participating in ARML is a definitive rite of passage for the nation's most talented math students.
format: Team Round -> Power Round -> Individual Round -> Relay Rounds.
eligibility: High school students; Teams of 15 (Regional).
howToApply: 1. Qualify for a local regional team in the spring. 2. Participate in regional training. 3. Travel to one of the four host sites.

title: US National Chemistry Olympiad (USNCO) SCALACS
description: The USNCO Southern California section competition is one of the most competitive regional qualifiers for the national chemistry team. It is prestigious due to the high density of elite academic talent in the region and serves as the primary gateway to the national exam. Students who perform well here demonstrate mastery of advanced laboratory concepts and chemical theory.
format: Local Exam (MCQ) -> National Exam (for top qualifiers).
eligibility: High school students in the Southern California region.
howToApply: 1. Register via the SCALACS website. 2. Take local exam in early March. 3. Advance to National Exam in April.

title: PhysicsBowl
description: PhysicsBowl is a fast-paced, accessible competition organized by the AAPT that tests students across all domains of introductory physics. It is prestigious for its large international scale, with over 10,000 students competing for top scores in specific regional divisions. The 45-minute format rewards quick thinking and a broad knowledge base rather than deep proof-based analysis.
format: 40 multiple-choice questions in 45 minutes.
eligibility: High school students; Division 1 (1st year) or Division 2 (2nd year).
howToApply: 1. School registers for the contest. 2. Receive online codes for students. 3. Administer exam during March/April window.

title: USAAAO First Round
description: The USA Astronomy and Astrophysics Olympiad is the premier competition for students aiming to represent the US on the international stage. It is prestigious for its highly specialized content, requiring students to master celestial mechanics, astrophysics, and observational astronomy. The first round is a rigorous filter that selects the top talent for the National Astronomy Competition.
format: Online multiple-choice exam focusing on astronomy and astrophysics.
eligibility: High school students; US Citizens or residents.
howToApply: 1. Register online in January. 2. Pay registration fee. 3. Take online exam on February 9.

title: Zero Robotics High School Tournament
description: Zero Robotics is a prestigious coding competition where students write algorithms to control NASA's Astrobee robots on the International Space Station. It is interesting for its combination of autonomous robotics and environmental science, with the 2026 theme being 'Galactic Greenhouse.' Finalists have their code actually executed in space by astronauts.
format: Code Submission -> Virtual Simulations -> Final Fly-off on the ISS.
eligibility: High school students; Teams of 5-20.
howToApply: 1. Register team on MIT portal. 2. Submit practice code by Jan 23. 3. Submit final code for simulation rounds.

title: SourceAmerica Design Challenge
description: The SourceAmerica Design Challenge is a unique engineering competition focused on creating assistive technology for the workplace. It is prestigious for its social impact, as students work to solve real-world accessibility barriers for people with disabilities. Participants gain experience in the human-centered design process and technical engineering documentation.
format: Project Submission (Video + Technical Documentation) -> Virtual Finals.
eligibility: High school and college students; Teams of 2 or more.
howToApply: 1. Identify a workplace challenge for a person with a disability. 2. Engineer a solution. 3. Submit final video and report by Feb 2.

title: M3 Challenge
description: The MathWorks Math Modeling (M3) Challenge is the nation's premier math modeling contest, requiring teams to solve a complex, open-ended problem in a 14-hour window. It is prestigious for emphasizing process and synthesis over pure calculation, simulating the way professional mathematicians and data scientists work. Top teams win substantial scholarships totaling over $100,000.
format: 14-hour intensive modeling session; Open-ended problem.
eligibility: High school juniors and seniors; Teams of 3-5.
howToApply: 1. Register team on SIAM portal. 2. Choose a 14-hour block during the competition weekend. 3. Submit final solution paper.

title: DNA Day Essay Contest
description: The DNA Day Essay Contest, hosted by the American Society of Human Genetics, challenges students to explore the ethical and scientific implications of genomics. It is prestigious for its global reach and its timing, celebrating the discovery of the double helix. Winning essays reflect a deep understanding of human genetics and its impact on medicine and society.
format: Essay submission (750 words max).
eligibility: Grades 9-12 globally.
howToApply: 1. Review annual prompt on ASHG website. 2. Write 750-word essay. 3. Submit through the ASHG portal.

title: EngineerGirl Writing Contest
description: The EngineerGirl Writing Contest is a unique STEM outreach program that uses creative writing to explore engineering concepts. It is prestigious for its sponsorship by the National Academy of Engineering and its focus on diversifying the field. The 2026 theme encourages students to research and write about how engineering solutions can support sustainable communities.
format: Creative writing or art submission based on annual theme.
eligibility: Grades 3-12 (Boys and Girls); US Residents.
howToApply: 1. Review theme on EngineerGirl website. 2. Write essay/poem or create art. 3. Submit via online form.

title: MathCounts (Chapter Competition)
description: MathCounts is the leading middle school math competition series in the United States, known for its high-energy 'Countdown Round' buzzer matches. It is prestigious for building foundational skills in the country's youngest mathematical talents and providing a clear path to national visibility. Winning at the chapter level is a significant local achievement that qualifies students for state-level glory.
format: Sprint Round -> Target Round -> Team Round -> Countdown Round (Buzzer).
eligibility: Middle school students (Grades 6-8).
howToApply: 1. School registers with national office. 2. Students train for chapter event. 3. Attend regional competition in February.

title: USAPhO (USA Physics Olympiad)
description: The USAPhO is the second, most difficult round of the physics olympiad selection process, limited to the top 400 students in the nation. It is prestigious for its calculus-based problems that mirror the difficulty of undergraduate physics courses. Success in this round is the primary factor in being selected for the 20-person U.S. Physics Team training camp.
format: 3-hour proof-based exam covering mechanics and electromagnetism.
eligibility: Top 400 scorers from F=ma exam.
howToApply: 1. Qualify via F=ma exam. 2. Receive official invitation. 3. Sit for proctored exam at school or local center.

title: ExploraVision
description: ExploraVision, sponsored by Toshiba and the NSTA, challenges students to imagine future technologies based on current scientific trends. It is prestigious for being the world's largest K-12 science competition, focusing on innovation and long-term vision. Teams must research existing technology and project how it could evolve over 20 years to solve global problems.
format: Project Report (11 pages) + 5 Mock Website Pages.
eligibility: K-12 students in the US and Canada; Teams of 2-4.
howToApply: 1. Form a team and select an adult mentor. 2. Research current and future tech. 3. Submit final report and mock-up.

title: National Science Bowl
description: The National Science Bowl, hosted by the Department of Energy, is a high-speed buzzer competition that tests students across all STEM disciplines. It is prestigious for its rigorous regional qualification process and its focus on team-based speed and accuracy. The national finals in Washington D.C. are a major celebration of STEM excellence involving hundreds of schools.
format: Regional Buzzer Tournament -> National Finals Round Robin -> Double Elimination.
eligibility: Middle and High School students; Teams of 4-5.
howToApply: 1. Register for local regional tournament. 2. Win the regional championship. 3. Travel to D.C. for national finals.

title: Dallas Regional Science & Engineering Fair
description: The Dallas Regional fair is one of the most competitive and well-funded regional fairs in the Texas ISEF pipeline. It is prestigious for its association with Beal Bank and Southern Methodist University, attracting top-tier research from the DFW metroplex. Winners here earn the coveted opportunity to compete at the state and international levels.
format: Poster presentation -> Judging Interviews -> Awards Ceremony.
eligibility: Grades 6-12 in Dallas area.
howToApply: 1. Register project with local fair by deadline. 2. Complete SRC/IRB approvals. 3. Present project at Fair Park in February.

title: Texas State Science & Engineering Fair (TXSEF)
description: TXSEF is a massive gathering of the state's brightest young researchers at Texas A&M University. It is prestigious for its high difficulty and large prize pool, acting as the final hurdle for many students aiming for ISEF qualification. The fair reflects the state's significant investment in STEM education and high-level research infrastructure.
format: Regional Qualification -> State Poster Defense -> Grand Prize Judging.
eligibility: Grades 6-12; Qualification via affiliated Texas regional fair.
howToApply: 1. Place in top tier at regional fair. 2. Complete state registration by March deadline. 3. Present in College Station.

title: Georgia Science & Engineering Fair
description: The Georgia Science & Engineering Fair is the state's premier forum for middle and high school students to present original research. It is prestigious for its long-standing history and its role in selecting the state's delegation for the International Science Fair. The event provides students with feedback from university professors and industry professionals.
format: Regional Fair -> State Competition (Athens, GA).
eligibility: Grades 6-12; Qualification via Georgia regional fair.
howToApply: 1. Win at a regional GSEF-affiliated fair. 2. Submit state-level paperwork. 3. Attend competition at UGA in March.

title: Florida State Science & Engineering Fair (SSEF)
description: SSEF Florida is a highly prestigious event that showcases the research of over 900 students from across the state. It is interesting for its high concentration of aerospace and marine biology projects, reflecting Florida's unique economic sectors. Winners are awarded significant scholarships and the chance to represent Florida at ISEF.
format: Regional Qualification -> State Poster Defense (Lakeland, FL).
eligibility: Grades 6-12; Qualification via Florida regional fair.
howToApply: 1. Qualify through one of Florida's regional fairs. 2. Submit final abstract and certification. 3. Present project in Lakeland.

title: New York State Science & Engineering Fair (NYSSEF)
description: NYSSEF is the primary gateway for New York students to reach the International Science and Engineering Fair. It is prestigious for its high academic standards and its two-round system, which utilizes virtual video judging to ensure a broad reach across the state. The in-person finals bring together the elite top scorers for a final defense.
format: Round 1 (Virtual Video) -> Round 2 (In-person Finals at Queens Hall of Science).
eligibility: Grades 9-12; New York State residents.
howToApply: 1. Register project online by Jan 23. 2. Upload video presentation by Jan 30. 3. Attend in-person finals on March 30.

title: Mass State Science & Engineering Fair (HS)
description: The Massachusetts State Science Fair for High School students is held at MIT, providing one of the most academically rigorous environments in the country. It is prestigious for its deep connections to the Cambridge biotech and tech hubs, with many judges being industry leaders or MIT faculty. Success here is a definitive signal of high-level research capability in the STEM world.
format: Regional Fair -> State Fair (MIT, Cambridge).
eligibility: High school students in Massachusetts.
howToApply: 1. Win at a regional Massachusetts fair. 2. Register with MSEF state office. 3. Present project at MIT in April.

title: JSHS Illinois Regional
description: The Junior Science and Humanities Symposium in Illinois focuses on the oral presentation of original student research, mimicking a professional scientific conference. It is prestigious for its focus on communication and formal peer review, with winners advancing to the National JSHS. Participating students gain significant experience in academic defense and public speaking.
format: Paper Submission -> Oral Presentation (12 min) + Q&A (6 min).
eligibility: High school students in Illinois.
howToApply: 1. Register and submit abstract by Jan 21. 2. If selected, prepare full paper. 3. Present at SIU on Feb 21-22.

title: JSHS Northern New England
description: The Northern New England JSHS brings together the best student researchers from Maine, New Hampshire, and Vermont. It is prestigious for being one of the oldest regional symposia in the program, offering students the chance to compete for undergraduate tuition scholarships. The event highlights the diverse environmental and engineering research prevalent in the region.
format: Abstract Submission -> Symposium Defense (U-Maine).
eligibility: High school students in ME, NH, and VT.
howToApply: 1. Submit abstract and paper via the JSHS portal. 2. Receive invitation to symposium. 3. Present work on February 27.

title: JSHS Connecticut Regional
description: The Connecticut JSHS, held at UConn Health, is a premier showcase for the state's top high school research projects. It is prestigious for its emphasis on clinical research and biotechnology, given its location at a major medical university. Winners advance to the National JSHS and receive significant scholarship awards.
format: Paper Submission -> Poster Session -> Oral Presentation.
eligibility: High school students in Connecticut.
howToApply: 1. Register online in the autumn. 2. Submit final abstract by Feb 12. 3. Attend symposium at UConn on Feb 28.

title: Brain Bee Atlanta Regional
description: The Atlanta Regional Brain Bee is a high-stakes competition focused on neuroscience, hosted by Emory University. It is prestigious for its connection to world-class neurology research and its role in selecting the regional representative for the USA National Brain Bee. Students must master complex brain anatomy, physiology, and pathology.
format: Written Quiz -> Oral Buzzer Round -> Anatomy Identification.
eligibility: High school students in the Atlanta metro area.
howToApply: 1. Register via Eventbrite or Emory portal. 2. Study the 'Brain Facts' guide. 3. Compete in March at Emory.

title: Brain Bee Bay Area
description: The Bay Area Brain Bee is one of the nation's largest neuroscience competitions, held in the heart of the global biotech hub. It is prestigious for drawing competitors from Silicon Valley's top schools and its collaboration with UC Berkeley or Stanford faculty. Winners earn the right to compete at the National Brain Bee and gain exposure to the neuro-tech industry.
format: Written Round -> Oral Elimination Round.
eligibility: High school students in the San Francisco Bay Area.
howToApply: 1. Register via the official Weebly site. 2. Review neuroscience curricula. 3. Attend the April event in San Francisco.

title: USA National Brain Bee
description: The USA National Brain Bee is the ultimate destination for the nation's best young neuroscientists, held at UC Irvine. It is prestigious for its high difficulty, requiring students to diagnose simulated patients and identify real human brain samples. The winner represents the United States at the International Brain Bee.
format: Patient Diagnosis -> Anatomy Lab -> Written Exam -> Oral Round.
eligibility: Regional Brain Bee winners.
howToApply: 1. Win an affiliated regional brain bee. 2. Receive invitation for nationals. 3. Travel to UC Irvine in April.

title: University of Toronto National Biology Competition (NBC)
description: The Toronto NBC is Canada's premier biology competition and is open to international students, making it a major North American benchmark. It is prestigious for offering scholarships to the University of Toronto, one of the world's top research institutions. The exam is known for its rigorous coverage of ecology, genetics, and cell biology.
format: 50 multiple-choice questions in 75 minutes.
eligibility: High school students globally.
howToApply: 1. Register through a school or test center. 2. Pay registration fee. 3. Take online exam on April 8.

title: Chem 13 News Exam
description: The Chem 13 News Exam is a prestigious chemistry competition hosted by the University of Waterloo for Grade 12 students. it is interesting for its high difficulty, often exceeding the standard high school curriculum to challenge the best chemistry minds in North America. Top performers are recognized globally and are highly sought after by university science departments.
format: 40 multiple-choice questions in 75 minutes.
eligibility: Grade 12 students (or equivalent).
howToApply: 1. Register through your school by April 24. 2. Pay the exam fee. 3. Take the exam online on May 7.

title: Avogadro Exam
description: The Avogadro Exam is the University of Waterloo's flagship chemistry contest for Grade 11 students. It is prestigious for its emphasis on the foundational concepts of chemistry and is widely used as a benchmark for student placement in advanced courses. The exam's large scale and rigorous standards make it a key indicator of early scientific potential.
format: 40 multiple-choice questions in 75 minutes.
eligibility: Grade 11 students (or equivalent).
howToApply: 1. School registers students by May 1. 2. Receive login credentials. 3. Take the exam on May 14.

title: Purple Comet! Math Meet (Middle School)
description: The middle school division of the Purple Comet! Math Meet offers younger students a flexible, high-level international team competition. It is prestigious for its community-building aspect, as it is free and allows schools of all sizes to participate globally. The problems are designed to challenge team logic and collaboration in a high-pressure, timed online environment.
format: Team round: 20 questions in 60 minutes.
eligibility: Middle school students; Teams of up to 6.
howToApply: 1. Teacher registers team for free. 2. Select 60-minute window during April. 3. Submit team answers via portal.

title: Georgia Tech High School Math Day (HSMD)
description: Georgia Tech's HSMD is the most significant math competition in the Southeastern United States, attracting talent from several states. It is prestigious for its association with the Georgia Institute of Technology and its dual format of multiple-choice and proof-based rounds. Winning here is a major credential for students applying to elite engineering programs.
format: Multiple Choice Round -> Proof-Based Ciphering Round -> Awards.
eligibility: High school students in the Southeast US.
howToApply: 1. Register online via Georgia Tech portal. 2. Pay registration fee. 3. Attend competition in Atlanta.

title: Univ Alabama Math Tournament
description: The University of Alabama Math Tournament is a long-standing tradition (over 40 years) that serves as a cornerstone of competitive math in the South. It is prestigious for its history and its focus on the 'Ciphering Match,' a high-speed live problem-solving event. It draws the best teams from Alabama and neighboring states to compete for top rankings.
format: Comprehensive Written Exam -> Team Ciphering Match (Live).
eligibility: High school students; Teams of 4.
howToApply: 1. School registers via UA Math Dept. 2. Pay tournament fee. 3. Attend event in Tuscaloosa.

title: College of Charleston Math Meet
description: The College of Charleston Math Meet is a prestigious multi-format event known for its longevity and its unique integration of various competition styles. It is interesting for its inclusion of 'timed sprints' and written exams, offering a well-rounded challenge for different types of mathematical thinkers. The meet has been a regional favorite for decades.
format: Timed Sprints -> Individual Written Exam -> Team Competition.
eligibility: High school students; US residents.
howToApply: 1. Register online by Feb 6. 2. Prepare for multi-format rounds. 3. Compete in Charleston on Feb 21.

title: American Invitational Mathematics Examination II (AIME II)
description: AIME II is the alternate date for the American Invitational Mathematics Examination, providing the same high-level challenge for students with scheduling conflicts. It is equally prestigious as AIME I and follows the same rigorous format, serving as the final filter for the USAMO and USAJMO. Success on the AIME II is a hallmark of elite high school mathematical ability.
format: 15 short-answer questions in 3 hours; No calculators.
eligibility: Qualifiers from AMC 10/12 A or B with scheduling conflict.
howToApply: 1. Qualify via AMC 10/12. 2. Register for AIME II via test center. 3. Take proctored exam.

title: USA Junior Mathematical Olympiad (USAJMO)
description: The USAJMO is the premier proof-based math competition for younger high schoolers (AMC 10 qualifiers). it is prestigious for its extreme difficulty, as it identifies the future stars of the IMO team through nine hours of rigorous proofs over two days. Selection for the USAJMO is one of the highest individual academic honors a student in the 10th grade or below can achieve.
format: 9-hour proof-based exam over two days; 6 problems.
eligibility: AMC 10 and AIME qualifiers (Grade 10 and below).
howToApply: 1. Achieve qualifying AMC 10 + AIME index score. 2. Receive invitation. 3. Take two-day exam at registered center.

title: USA Mathematical Olympiad (USAMO)
description: The USAMO is the ultimate domestic mathematics competition in the United States, selecting the training camp participants for the International Mathematical Olympiad. It is exceptionally prestigious, consisting of six incredibly difficult proof-based problems over nine hours. Being a USAMO qualifier is a rare distinction that signals a student is among the top 250 mathematicians in the country.
format: 9-hour proof-based exam over two days; 6 problems.
eligibility: AMC 12 and AIME qualifiers (Grade 12 and below).
howToApply: 1. Achieve qualifying AMC 12 + AIME index score. 2. Receive invitation. 3. Take two-day exam at registered center.

title: Canadian Chemistry Contest (CCC)
description: The CCC is the flagship chemistry competition for high school students in Canada, designed to identify talent for the International Chemistry Olympiad. It is prestigious for its high technical standards and its coverage of advanced physical, organic, and analytical chemistry. Success here is a key factor in admission to top Canadian science and engineering programs.
format: Multiple choice and written problem sets.
eligibility: High school students in Canada.
howToApply: 1. Register via the Chemical Institute of Canada. 2. Pay registration fee. 3. Take exam on April 22.

title: USA Astronomy and Astrophysics Olympiad (National)
description: The National Astronomy Competition is the second and final round of the US selection process for the international olympiad. It is prestigious for its focus on data-heavy astrophysical problems and celestial mechanics at a collegiate level. The top scorers from this round are invited to the elite training camp to represent the United States globally.
format: Proof-based problems and data analysis exam.
eligibility: Top qualifiers from USAAAO First Round.
howToApply: 1. Qualify through first-round exam. 2. Receive invitation to NAC. 3. Attend national competition in April.

title: MathWorks Math Modeling (M3) Challenge Finals
description: The M3 Challenge Finals bring together the top teams from the 14-hour national modeling round for a live defense in New York City. It is prestigious for its simulation of professional quantitative consulting, with students presenting their models to a panel of Ph.D. mathematicians. The event awards significant scholarships and provides students with elite networking opportunities.
format: Presentation and Oral Defense of 14-hour model.
eligibility: Top 6 national qualifying teams from M3 Challenge.
howToApply: 1. Submit top-tier model in February round. 2. Receive invitation to finals. 3. Present work in NYC.

title: VEX Robotics World Championship (St. Louis)
description: The VEX World Championship is the largest robotics competition in the world, with the 2026 event moving to a prestigious new location in St. Louis. It is interesting for its high-intensity matches and the collaborative 'alliance' system that forces teams from different countries to work together. Winning here is the ultimate achievement in middle and high school engineering and autonomous programming.
format: Regional Qualifier -> Divisional Playoffs -> Round Robin -> Finals.
eligibility: Middle and High School students; Qualification via state/regional event.
howToApply: 1. Win at a state or regional V5RC event. 2. Register for Worlds via RECF. 3. Compete in St. Louis in April.
